Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Story: My phone buzzed on the passenger seat, and I glanced at the screen during a red light. It was Mia, my closest friend, her message sharp and short: “Wow, didn’t know you felt that way.” My heart dropped. She’d misunderstood my earlier text, and I could tell she was hurt. I knew I should call her right away, clear things up before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do—communicate, don’t let things fester. But as the light turned green, I eased the taxi forward, only to see the road ahead squeeze into a single lane, orange cones everywhere, and a cluster of kids waiting to cross. My job demanded my full attention now—eyes on the road, hands on the wheel, every sense alert. I couldn’t risk a distraction, not here, not with children so close. The urge to grab my phone and call Mia gnawed at me, but the responsibility of driving safely pressed just as hard. I felt torn, the weight of both roles heavy on my chest, each demanding something I couldn’t give at the same time.
